definitions.definition: to fix something to something else, usually with a sticky substance; to become fixed to something in this way

examples.text: He stuck a stamp on the envelope.
We used glue to stick the broken pieces together.
I stuck the photos into an album.
Her wet clothes were sticking to her body.
The glue's useless—the pieces just won't stick.
Her wet hair was sticking to her head.
I forgot to stick a stamp on the envelope.

definitions.definition: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move

examples.text: This drawer keeps sticking.
The key has stuck in the lock.

definitions.definition: to push something, usually a sharp object, into something; to be pushed into something

examples.text: The nurse stuck the needle into my arm.
Don't stick your fingers through the bars of the cage.
I found a nail sticking in the tyre.
He simply stuck a pin in at random among the names of the candidates.
She stuck a finger into the sugar bowl.
The little boy had stuck his head through the railings.

definitions.definition: to put something in a place, especially quickly or carelessly

examples.text: Stick your bags down there.
He stuck his hands in his pockets and strolled off.
Can you stick this on the noticeboard?
Peter stuck his head around the door and said, ‘Coffee, anyone?’
He stuck the note through her letter box.
Stick 'em up! *(= Put your hands above your head—I have a gun!)*

definitions.definition: used to say in a rude and angry way that you are not interested in what somebody has, offers, does, etc.

examples.text: I got sick of my boss's moaning and told him he could stick the job.

definitions.definition: to accept a difficult or unpleasant situation or person

examples.text: I don't know how you stick that job.
They’re always arguing—I can’t stick it any longer.
The problem is, my mother can't stick my boyfriend.
John can't stick living with his parents.

definitions.definition: to become accepted

examples.text: The police couldn't **make the charges stick** *(= show them to be true)*.
His friends called him Bart and **the name has stuck** *(= has become the name that everyone calls him)*.

definitions.definition: to say that you will not take any more cards
people remember and believe the bad things they hear about other people, even if they are later shown to be false
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation

examples.text: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

definitions.definition: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to give your opinion, advice, etc. without being asked and when it is probably not wanted

examples.text: I was getting along very nicely until Patrick stuck his oar in.

definitions.definition: to form the shape of a V with the two fingers nearest your thumb and raise your hand in the air with the back part of it facing somebody, done to be rude to them or to show them that you are angry

examples.text: She enjoys sticking two fingers up to convention.

definitions.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way

examples.text: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

definitions.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice

examples.text: It stood out a mile that she was lying.

definitions.definition: to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation

examples.text: I wonder if the press will stick the boot in?

definitions.definition: to be remembered for a long time

examples.text: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

definitions.definition: to be difficult or impossible to say

examples.text: She wanted to say how sorry she was but the words seemed to stick in her throat.

definitions.definition: to be difficult or impossible to accept; to make you angry
to do or say something when there is a risk that you may be wrong

examples.text: I’ll stick my neck out and say that Bill is definitely the best candidate for the job.

definitions.definition: to try to become involved in something that should not involve you

examples.text: He's always sticking his nose into other people's business.

definitions.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way

examples.text: The blue building stuck out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you'll stick out like a sore thumb.

definitions.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice

examples.text: It stuck out a mile that she was lying.

definitions.definition: to refuse to change your mind about something even when other people are trying to persuade you that you are wrong
to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you

wordOrigin: verb Old English stician, of Germanic origin; related to German sticken ‘embroider’, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek stizein ‘to prick’, stigma ‘a mark’ and Latin instigare ‘spur on’. Early senses included ‘pierce’ and ‘remain fixed (by its embedded pointed end)’.
